Name: Business Administration, B.A.
Description:
['
There are five tracks within the BA degree in business administration. Students will select a track when they declare a major in business administration. In cases where students decide to change tracks, they will speak with their advisor and complete appropriate paperwork which will be submitted to the Department Chair. Students in all tracks will take six core foundational courses, a common capstone course, and six track specific requirements. Track requirements vary in accordance with the track focus and may consist of track required courses, primary track electives, and secondary track electives. Any course substitutions or waivers must be approved by the Business and Accounting (BAC) Department Chair. Other courses may be added to the course lists as approved by the BAC Department.
To fulfill major requirements, students must have at least a 2.00 grade point average for courses used to satisfy the major requirements. 
']

credits)', 'A student may complete this requirement through either:', 'International Business track majors must have at least one experience in learning about and engaging with another culture and business environment. We strongly recommend International Business majors participate in a Study Away experience outside of the US. Furman supports semester-long Study Away programs, MayX Study Away courses (2 to 3 weeks in May), and international internships. International internships are also promoted in certain Study Away programs, the Freeman Fellowships, and other opportunities through the Office of Internships. We encourage you to speak with your advisors, the Rinker Center for Study Away and International Education, and the Internship Office  to learn more about the possibilities.', 'For those students unable to participate in a Study Away program, the International Business Engagement requirement may be met by completing an internship in the US with a firm or organization involved in international business.', 'A course used to satisfy the International Business Engagement requirement may also be used to satisfy the International Business Track Elective requirements.']]

Name: Chemistry, Biochemistry Track, B.S.
Description:
['
All students seeking the chemistry major are urged to begin the chemistry course sequence immediately in the first term of freshman year. They should also schedule required mathematics and physics courses as early as possible.
Participation in the annual summer undergraduate research program is accepted in lieu of CHM-502.
']

Name: Chemistry, Standard Track, B.S.
Description:
['
All students seeking the chemistry major are urged to begin the chemistry course sequence immediately in the first term of freshman year. They should also schedule required mathematics and physics courses as early as possible.
Participation in the annual summer undergraduate research program is accepted in lieu of CHM-502.
']

Name: Communication Studies, Media track, B.A.
Description:
['
To graduate with a major in Communication Studies students must take a minimum 36 credit hours and satisfy the requirements outlined in each course category below. Students must also have at least a 2.00 grade point average for courses used to satisfy major requirements.
Communication Studies: Media Majors complete foundational courses, media studies courses, and engaged learning experiences for a total of at least 36 hours in the major.
']

Name: Information Technology, B.A.
Description: ['\nTo fulfill major requirements, students must have at least a 2.00 grade point average for all computer science courses enrolled and all other courses enrolled satisfying major requirements.\n']
Info: [['h2 A major must include:', [['CSC-105 Intro to Computer Science', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60327&print']], [['CSC-121 Intro to Computer Programming', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60328&print']], [['CSC-122 Data Structures and Algorithms', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60329&print']], [['CSC-475 Seminar in Computer Science', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60353&print'], 'or'], [['CSC-502 Research', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60355&print']], ['at least two more CSC courses numbered 200 or greater with at least one of the courses numbered 300 or greater, and'], ['at least three other courses numbered 200 or greater in a cognate discipline with at least one course numbered 300 or greater.']], ['h2 and six Purposeful Pathways activities:', 'Earn credit, as determined by the Chair, for six Purposeful Pathways activities, with two from each from the following categories:', [], ['Career Exploration'], [], ['Professional Preparation'], [], ['Networking & Employer Engagement'], [], 'Participation in an Engaged Learning (Internship, Research) opportunity can be used to substitute for one of the required six events with prior approval from the Chair.'], ['h2 Further considerations', 'The cognate discipline includes courses leading to an award of a major in another field of study, where those courses have a clear IT component or applicability.  The capstone (CSC-475  or CSC-502 ) will serve to integrate the experiences. Specific cognate courses comprising a consistent theme for the IT major will be identified when the student declares their intent to pursue a major. The cognate discipline may not be Computer Science.']]

Name: Earth and Environmental Science, B.A.
Info: [['h2 Candidates for the B.A. degree must complete:', [['EES-111 Earth and the Silver Screen', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60357&print'], 'or'], [['EES-112 Environmental Science', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60358&print'], 'or'], [['EES-113 Natural Hazards and Natural Disasters', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60359&print'], 'or'], [['EES-115 Earth Systems', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60356&print']], [['EES-220 Mineralogy and Petrology I', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60363&print']]], ['h2 a mathematics course, appropriate for the discipline:', [['MTH-120 Introduction to Statistics', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60647&print'], 'or'], [['MTH-145 Calculus for Management, Life and Social Sciences', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61340&print'], 'or'], [['MTH-150 Analytic Geometry and Calculus I', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60643&print']]], ['h2 and, six more EES elective courses numbered 200 or above.'], ['h2 Further considerations', 'Students anticipating graduate study and professional work in earth and environmental sciences should obtain the B.S. degree. Name: Sustainability Science, B.S.
Description: ['\nThe Sustainability Science major focuses on the critical linkages between global environmental, human, and social systems and emphasizes complex systems analysis focusing on understanding sustainability related problems and assessing potential solutions.\n']
Info: [['h2 To fulfill major requirements, students must complete:', [['EES-112 Environmental Science', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60358&print']], [['SUS-120 Principles of Sustainability Science', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60390&print']], [['SUS-241 Social Systems', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60392&print']], [['SUS-242 Dynamic System Modeling', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60393&print']], [['SUS-474 Senior Capstone', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61505&print']], [['SUS-472 Research and Analysis', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60394&print']], ['or'], [['SUS-473 Sustainability Science Practicum', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60395&print']]], ['h2 Six additional electives numbered 200 or above:', [], ['at least 3 with SUS prefix'], [], ['at least 1 with EES prefix.'], [], ['Courses outside the department that fit the students personal pathway may be selected by working with the academic advisor and approval of the department chair.'], []], ['h2 Further considerations', 'It is strongly recommended that courses used to fulfill major requirements be chosen in consultation with a faculty advisor and intended academic or professional pathways.', 'Students interested in environmental and/or sustainability issues, but not wishing to major in the sciences may complete an interdisciplinary minor in Environmental Studies or B.A. in Earth and Environmental Sciences. Sustainability Science majors may also fulfill the requirements for the Environmental Studies interdisciplinary minor.']]

Name: Educational Studies, B.A.
Description:
['
The Educational Studies major is designed for students seeking careers where they will work with children and/or youth in environments other than a traditional classroom setting. Intended to grant opportunities to engage students in the study of education as a field of inquiry, this major provides an individualized and integrated pathway aligned within a liberal arts curriculum. A primary expectation of this program is that it will provide students a strong educational foundation to seek admission into graduate programs. Students completing this program have entered graduate programs and pursued careers in child life, speech pathology, camp directorships, student life/higher education administration, children and youth ministry, educational policy, advocacy, non-profit management, and others. Contact the Educational Studies Coordinator to learn more about this program.
Students must successfully complete all courses required in the major field of study (EDU) with a grade of C or higher.
']

Name: Teaching in Grades PK-12
Description:
['
Students wishing to pursue certification to teach Music Education in grades PK-12 complete a major in that academic discipline. Please refer to the appropriate departmental section of this catalog for additional information.
Students seeking certification in Music (grades PK-12) must complete one science course with a laboratory component.
']
Info: [['h2 Early Teaching Experience', 'In August, prior to the senior year, all elementary candidates seeking teacher certification participate in an early teaching experience on a full-time basis. This experience provides an opportunity for direct involvement in the opening of school when classroom routines and procedures are established. Candidates seeking certification are expected to assume some teaching responsibilities.']]

Name: Health Sciences, B.A.
Description:
['
Students interested in majoring in Health Sciences must seek early advice from a member of the faculty and declare the major with the department chair.
Students may pursue a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) or Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree in either field of study, but students may not double major in Health Sciences and Public Health. Students seeking a B.A. degree must complete all General Education Requirements  consistent with the B.A. degree. 
']
Info: [['h2 A major must include:', [['HSC-101 Wellness Concepts', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60505&print']], [['HSC-201 Research and Evaluation in Health Sciences', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60509&print']], [['HSC-205 Fundamentals of Public Health', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60516&print']], [['HSC-210 Anatomy and Physiology I', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60510&print']], [['HSC-211 Anatomy and Physiology II', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60511&print']]], ['h3 and, at least six additional HSC courses numbered greater than 211. Only one 4-credit 500-level course can be counted and may not include 503.']]

['
Students interested in majoring in Health Sciences must seek early advice from a member of the faculty and declare the major with the department chair.  
Students may pursue a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) or Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree in either field of study, but students may not double major in Health Sciences and Public Health. Students seeking a B.S. degree must successfully complete all General Education Requirements  consistent with the B.S. degree.  
']

Name: Public Health, B.A.
Description:
['
Students interested in majoring in Public Health must seek early advice from the department chair and should apply during the spring of their sophomore year. In addition to a written application, students must have successfully completed or be currently registered in HSC-205 Fundamentals of Public Health at the time of application. Admission to the major is selective.  
Majors may pursue a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) or Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree in either field of study, but students may not double major in Health Sciences and Public Health. Students seeking a B.A. degree must successfully complete all General Education Requirements  consistent with the B.A. degree. 
']

Name: Public Health, B.S.
Description:
['
Students interested in majoring in Public Health must seek early advice from the department chair and should apply during the spring of their sophomore year. In addition to a written application, students must have successfully completed or be currently registered in HSC-205 Fundamentals of Public Health at the time of application. Admission to the major is selective.  
Students may pursue a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) or Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree in either field of study, but students may not double major in Health Sciences and Public Health. Students seeking a B.S. degree must successfully complete all General Education Requirements  consistent with the B.S. degree. 
']

Name: Humanities Minor
Description:
['
Students design the minor through specific interest tracks that allow them to explore different current areas of the humanities that align with other emphases within the Furman curriculum. 

Fine arts/humanities: incorporating the academic aspects of the disciplines of music, theater arts, and visual art to be included in a students thesis, and performance or visual based aspects of those subject matters.
Environmental humanities: emphasizing concepts of nature and on the relationship between nature and culture, students combine quantitative studies of natural phenomena and address their effects on the nature and quality of human existence.
Digital humanities: a student can create some assessable content (data analysis, game design, digitizing paper archives for analysis), and write a paper showing the results of the research that went into that project and its application.
Global humanities: a comparative humanities research projects that study one issue or event from different/multiple hemispheric perspectives, from more than one continents perspective, or from at least one understudied culture or region.
Students may also design their own topic for the minor combining various areas of humanistic study.

Students must propose a topic area to the oversight committee for approval to declare the major. Interested students should contact Dr. Margaret Oakes, the minor chair.
']
Info: [['h2 To fulfill interdisciplinary minor requirements, students must successfully complete', ['Sixteen credits selected from at least three relevant humanities disciplines from a range of departments, depending on the students topic choice; at least 4 credits per discipline.'], [], ['Relevant disciplines could include Art History, Asian Studies, Classics, Communication Studies, English, History, Modern Languages and Literatures, Music History, Philosophy, Political Philosophy, Religion, or Theatre Studies. Some Anthropology courses approved by the Humanities Minor Chair and the Anthropology Major Chair may apply. Courses must not be skills courses such as language instruction or studio art.'], [], ['If a student has taken the two-course Studies in the Humanities freshman sequence that fulfill two GERs (', ['HUM-101', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61542&print'], 'and', ['HUM-102', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61543&print'], '), those two courses may be counted as one of the four for the minor.'], [['HUM-450 Humanities Capstone Symposium', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60632&print']]], ['h2 Further considerations', 'No more than two courses used to meet minor requirements can be completed through the same academic department, while only one course may also contribute to a students major. Courses contributing to requirements of the minor cannot be completed using the pass/no pass grading option.']]

Name: Journalism Minor
Description: ['\nStudents with a minor in journalism take 24 credits (6 courses) in journalism with a focus in newswriting and media production. Students must select courses from at least three disciplines, and only one course being used to satisfy a journalism minor requirement may also satisfy any of the requirements for the students major(s).\n']

Name: Linguistics Minor
Description: ['\nStudents must take courses with 3 different prefixes to complete a minor in Linguistics. Students will take 16 credits (1 required 4-credit course and 12 additional credits of electives) and will engage in a high-impact experience to fulfill the requirements of the minor. See below for the course and co-curricular options that satisfy the high-impact requirement.\n']

Likewise, 4 credits of Independent Study, Independent Research, and Directed Independent Study (Courses numbered 501, 502, and 504) may be used as minor courses with approval of the oversight committee. Furthermore, directed summer research experiences (TFA-002) may be considered for use as electives with approval, along with the submission of a substantive research paper to be reviewed by the committee. Other courses, such as first year seminars and study away programs, may be considered on a case-by-case basis.']]

Name: Musical Theatre Minor
Description:
['
The Musical Theatre minor, interdisciplinary in nature, is a 16-24 credit program that incorporates the study of acting, dance and the vocal arts. The program is open to all Furman students, regardless of major, through an audition process.
All MT IDS minors must participate in at least 2 full productions in the Music department and/or the Theatre Arts department in order to complete the minor.
']

from the students major department.  At least 12-credits must be from non-FYW courses and above the entry level (100).  Only one course can be a May Experience course and only one course can be a FYW. No pass/fail courses options can count toward the concentration.', 'Potential May X courses include EDU-265: International Perspectives on Public Education (May X-travel study), POL 416 Farm, and EDU-115: Depiction of Schools on Film.', 'The Interdisciplinary Minor Oversight Committee will continue to review the content of potential FYW courses based on the relevance of those courses to (i) exposing students to how individuals come to understand larger issues through social institutions; and/or (ii) explicitly studying scientific intersections in specific disciplines including philosophy, history or religion. Potential FYWs include FYW-1139: God and Darwin, FYW-1146: Neuroethics, FYW-1120: Medicine, Morality and Culture, FYW 1105: Disease and Culture, and FYW-1127 To Walk the Land.']]

Name: Visual Strategy Minor
Description: ['\nStudents pursuing a minor in Visual Strategy must successfully complete 24 hours of course credit including at least one course from each of three separate disciplines. A student may only count 1 course (4 hours) toward both a major program and the minor program. In addition, students in this minor will participate in a culminating presentation of their visual work or works in-progress at Furman Engaged or another public venue during their senior year.\n']

Name: Military Science
Description:
['
The Reserve Officers Training Corps (ROTC) courses prepare young men and women to become leaders as commissioned Officers in the U. S. Army, Army Reserve or Army National Guard.
Any student may take basic courses (MSL 101, MSL 102, MSL 201 and MSL 202) without incurring a military obligation. Courses numbered 301 and greater are open to contracted ROTC cadets only. Cadets must pursue a bachelors or masters degree during their tenure.
']
Info: [['h2 Students seeking a commission must complete the following to be eligible to serve as an Officer in the U.S. Army:'], ['h3 The basic course sequence by the end of sophomore year OR receive credit for Basic Camp, JROTC in high school or successful prior service with the U.S. Army:', [['MSL-101 Introduction to the Army', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60669&print']], [['MSL-102 Foundations of Agile and Adaptive Leadership', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60670&print']], [['MSL-201 Leadership and Ethics', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60672&print']], [['MSL-202 Decision Making and Army Doctrine', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60673&print']]], ['h3 The advanced course sequence:', [['MSL-301 Training Management and the Warfighting Functions', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60674&print']], [['MSL-302 Applied Leadership', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60675&print']], [['MSL-401 Developmental Leadership', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60676&print']], [['MSL-402 Adaptive Leadership', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60677&print']]], ['h3 And five additional criteria:', [], ['successfully complete the 38-day Advance Camp at Fort Knox, Kentucky, the summer before the final year of the program, typically between the junior and senior year'], [], ['pass the Army Combat Fitness Test (ACFT)'], [], ['execute the Combat Water Survival Test'], [], ['pass', ['HST-124 War, Military and Society in American History', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61448&print']], [], ['and, meet or exceed all university degree requirements to earn a bachelors degree or masters degree.'], []]]

Name: French, B.A.
Info: [['h2 A major normally consists of at least eight courses beyond FRN-201 and usually includes:', [['FRN-214 French Conversation', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60702&print'], 'or', ['FRN-215 French Composition', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60703&print']], ['at least 28 more credits in French courses numbered 220 or greater including at least one course numbered between 400 and 470.']], ['h2 Further considerations', 'All majors must enroll in at least one course on campus in their major language during both their junior and senior years. All majors are also strongly encouraged to participate in a study away program before the spring term of their senior year.'], ['h2 Teaching in Secondary Schools', 'Students seeking a career in secondary school teaching must complete a major in the field to obtain a teacher certification. They may take advantage of the Master of Arts in Teaching (M.A.T.) graduate program. Please consult with the Education Department.']]

Name: Dual-Degree Engineering Program, Applied Physics B.S.
Description:
['
The dual-degree engineering program normally consists of three years at Furman and two to three years at one of our affiliated schools: Clemson University or the Georgia Institute of Technology. The Furman degree is awarded with a major in either Applied Physics or Physics. Degree requirements vary depending on the major pursued at Furman and the engineering school attended. Additional details and requirements are available from the department and can be found on the department web site: physics.furman.edu.
The bachelors degree at Furman is awarded after successful completion of an appropriate portion of the engineering curriculum at the other school. The engineering degree is awarded upon completion of the entire program. A minimum grade point average of 2.60 is required to declare a major in the dual-degree program.
']
Info: [['h2 Students seeking the dual-degree major in pre-engineering must complete:', [['CHM-110 Foundations of Chemistry', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60238&print']], [['CHM-115 Kinetics, Thermodynamics and the Environment', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60239&print']], [['MTH-151 Analytic Geometry and Calculus II', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60644&print']], [['MTH-160 Vectors and Matrices', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60645&print']], [['MTH-250 Vector Calculus', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60648&print']], [['MTH-255 Differential Equations', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60649&print']], [['PHY-111 General Physics I', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60991&print']], [['PHY-112 General Physics II', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60992&print']], [['PHY-311 Classical Mechanics I', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60996&print']], [['PHY-321 Electromagnetic Theory I', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=60998&print']], [['PHY-331 Thermodynamics', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61000&print']], ['additional CSC, ENG, and other courses as specified by the destination engineering program']]]

Name: Sociology, B.A.
Description: ['\nTo graduate with a major in sociology, a student must have a cumulative grade point average of at least 2.0 for all sociology courses\n']
Info: [['h2 A major consists of 36 credits, and must include:'], ['h3 22 credits of core courses,', [['SOC-101 Introduction to Sociology', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61165&print']], [['SOC-301 Sociological Theory', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61186&print']], [['SOC-302 Methods of Social Research', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61187&print']], [['SOC-303 Quantitative Research Seminar', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61188&print']], [['SOC-304 Qualitative Research Seminar', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61189&print']], ['SOC-465 Capstone Seminar (2 credits)']], ['h3 12 credits of sociology courses numbered between 200 and 299, including one of the following courses:', [['SOC-241 Social Class in America', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61179&print']], [['SOC-242 Sociology of Gender and Sexuality', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61180&print']], [['SOC-243 Race and Ethnic Relations', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61181&print']]], ['h3 and, a two-credit engaged learning experience selected from the list below:', ['Approved MayX or Study Away experiences'], [['IGD-101 Introduction to Intergroup Dialogue', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61666&print']], [['SOC-501 Independent Study', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61191&print']], [['SOC-503 Individualized Internship', 'https://catalog.furman.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=27&coid=61192&print']]]]
